text: well I think the releases are very
welcome but they don't seem to fit with
a pattern of change in the system so the
system the authoritarian system remains
intact this does as [ __ ] Riot have
alleged looked very much like a PR stunt
in the run-up to the Winter Olympics in
Sochi President Putin has been really
stung by the international criticism of
his crackdown on dissent and protest in
Russia and I think this is his way of
trying to deflect that criticism and
stop any more world leaders deciding to
not go to Sochi it's interesting I think
as many would say that actually he
wouldn't really care about public
opinion given the fact that if we look
at his ten years since becoming
president that lots has happened in that
time that actually the release of
political prisoners are something that
he's chosen to do right now and really
public opinion or world leaders opinion
ahead of Sochi doesn't really matter to
him well you say that but it's very
interesting the way in which he has
responded to lots of the criticism about
his crackdown on civil rights in the
past he's ignored those criticisms but
recently he's begun to respond and that
would indicate that he's feeling the
pressure that he realizes in PR terms on
a global scale his government is losing
the the hearts and minds of the wide
international public I can't think of
any other reason why now apart from
trying to begin a charm offensive in
there out to the Sochi Winter Olympics
there's no obvious reason why these the
races should happen now we were
reporting it was our main story on
Friday the release of Mikhail
Khodorkovsky where many said that this
was equally surprised and and a lot of
experts and pundits that we spoke to
also said about the reforms ahead of the
Winter Olympics but I'm keen to just pin
it down to the release of these women
again I know that you've been
campaigning for some time calling for
their release but but what is your over
your overview of the whole situation and
their detention in the first place and
how it's been played out there's no
doubt that I'm present Putin Russia has
gone backwards towards an increasingly
authoritarian autocratic style of
governments
you know we've seen so many attacks on
peaceful protesters even senior citizens
protesting for better pensions have been
subjected to violent attacks by the
police there's been the arrest of
opposition leaders the harassment of
environmental campaigners not just the
Greenpeace Arctic 30 but many other
Russian environmental activists who are
speaking out against ecological
destruction through industrialization
and toxic releases in their own country
so there's this pattern of repression
the state does not tolerate dissent very
well and indeed if you could create too
much trouble you'll very likely find
yourself you know submitted to
harassment possibly a beating maybe even
being framed on false charges something
that you're not a stranger to harassment
or other kind during the campaigns that
you've undertaken to support gay rights
I'm keen to find out from you Peter if
you think that after the Winter Olympics
if perhaps we're going to go back to
square one in Russia and this isn't
really a sign of long-term reform I
think we're already at square one
I think these releases are exceptional
well no it is a good move and but I
think it is it is motivated by desire to
charm the world and to soothe criticisms
in the run-up to the Winter Olympics I
think the system as it is has not
changed these releases are just
temporary blips they're a big
high-profile showy
ostentatious profession of so-called
liberalism but in reality the structure
of the system of authoritarianism of
state surveillance of harassment of
lawyers and journalists it is continuing
and that hasn't changed and I think
sadly it won't change I think once the
Sochi Winter Olympics are over there
will be a gradual return to the same
hardline ways of the past
